indications: Indications HIV infection in combination with other antiretroviral drugs
name: DIDANOSINE
cautions:
Cautions 
(From Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors: British National Formulary)
Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors; also history
of pancreatitis (preferably avoid, otherwise extreme caution, see
also below); peripheral neuropathy or hyperuricaemia (see under Side-effects); ophthalmological examination (including visual acuity, colour vision,
and dilated fundus examination) recommended annually or if visual changes occur; interactions:  Appendix 1 (didanosine)Pancreatitis Suspend
treatment if serum lipase raised (even if asymptomatic) or if symptoms
of pancreatitis develop; discontinue if pancreatitis confirmed. Whenever possible avoid concomitant treatment
with other drugs known to cause pancreatic toxicity (e.g. intravenous pentamidine isetionate); monitor closely if concomitant
therapy unavoidable. Since significant elevations of
triglycerides cause pancreatitis monitor closely if elevated
side-effects:
Side-effects see notes above; also pancreatitis (see also under
Cautions), liver failure, non-cirrhotic portal hypertension, anaphylactic
reactions, peripheral neuropathy (switch to another antiretroviral
if peripheral neuropathy develops), diabetes mellitus, hypoglycaemia,
acute renal failure, rhabdomyolysis, dry eyes, retinal and optic nerve
changes, dry mouth, parotid gland enlargement, sialadenitis, alopecia,
hyperuricaemia (suspend if raised significantly)
doses:
adult under 60 kg 250 mg
daily in 1–2 divided doses, 60 kg and over 400 mg daily in 1–2 divided
doses; child under 18 years see BNF for Children
pregnancy:
Pregnancy manufacturer advises use only if potential benefit
outweighs risk
